author: bayard
msg: Coders often put a constant into their code. It either goes in an
interface or a class and often looks like:
public final static int MAGIC = 1;
or
public final static String port = "80";
This has a few problems.
One, it is hard to keep state about more than one value in a String or
an int. When the constant is upgraded to get more functionality,
there are numerous APIs that take an int or a String.
Two, it pushes lazy coding style. People happily stick a 1 in somewhere,
or "80" and the compiler/program doesn't stop them.
Three, it creates unobvious APIs.
public void createServer(int) is hard to judge,
public void createServer(Constant) is easier,
public void createServer(PortNumber)  where PortNumber extends Constant
is easiest, though not always necessary.
I'm a firm believer in the use of the Constant class.
